author: @nilpo
text: I don't mean to be a stickler, but public key authentication isn't any more secure than password-based authentication. Keys aren't susceptible to capture by keyloggers, however, they introduce the risk of Trust On First Use on which they rely. Not a fair trade off.  The only truly secure method for SSH is to use certificate-based authentication which validates both the user and the host. You can enhance even that with two-factor authentication or other additional methods.

author: @CZghost
text: Windows doesn't have ability to run "ssh-copy-id" since there isn't such command (neighter internal nor external), I have to do it manually on Windows. Which is actually okay, but if Microsoft wants to integrate Windows into Linux more, I guess that kind of command should be available. Thanks for insight into how SSH works with keys.  Well, I have to confess, actually, guys. Normally I think about things, but for some reason I had quite a brain fart when I tried to generate a key on my computer and tried to pull it using remote machine (yes, I am using virtual machines for this kind of testing) from the main machine. It didn't work. Then I realised that I have been using that command wrong. I actually need to use it on the same machine I generate the key on, which is something I should have known :D Yeah, a little brain fart, but I managed :D

author: @vsrajan
text: Hi Corey, great video. 1 question though. If you disable password-based logins and then want to authorize a new user to be able to login, how do you set up key-based authentication for the new user? ssh-copy-id will not work as pwds are disabled on the remote host. How would you configure the public key for the new user? I hacked this by logging in as root, manually creating the .ssh folder, copying over the public key from another user and setting the appropriate permissions, and changing the owner for the .ssh folder and the key file from root back to the user. This works. But very hacky. Are you aware of an easier way of doing this?

author: @Zeioth
text: I followed the entire process 3 times on my Manjaro clean install but I keep getting: 192.168.1.12: Permission denied (publickey).  EDIT: This shit took me the entire evening. Apparently on some distros must explicitly set permissions for your home directory like: chmod g-w ~/  Source: https://www.daveperrett.com/articles/2010/09/14/ssh-authentication-refused/

author: @kneekoo
text: Hi, Corey. I hope you still follow up on these comments, because I have a few questions that you might address in a new video. I know I can google these, but I really enjoyed this video for its simplicity and a new one with more details would certainly clarify things for more people, who don't even ask themselves these questions but benefit from knowing the answers.  1. Is it safe to share your public key with anyone, even by placing it on a website? 2. Is it worth having several key pairs if you want to authenticate to different servers? 3. Is it possible to have more key pairs on the same PC? 4. What's the best encryption algorithm and key size nowadays? -> here's a nice article, but it's from 2016: https://blog.g3rt.nl/upgrade-your-ssh-keys.html 5. How often should we generate new pairs, to be safe? 6. How about a few tips for managing the keys? Are there SSH key managers like password managers? Do we store them on encrypted USB drives or on a personal (Next/Own)cloud? etc.

author: @muijnckj
text: I would like to add that it is quite handy to make a file named 'config' in the local .ssh folder and put:  Host [your shortcode] HostName [hostname] IdentityFile ~/.ssh/[key file name] User [username]  ...  [copy the above for other servers]   You can then type in de terminal 'ssh [your shortcode]' and log in directly.
